# MS4 Municipal Stormwater Permits

## What is MS4?
Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System - stormwater infrastructure separate from sanitary sewers.

## Who Needs Permits?

### Phase I
- Large municipalities (>100,000 population)
- Medium municipalities (>100,000 pop in urbanized areas)
- Individual permits

### Phase II
- Small MS4s in urbanized areas
- General permit coverage
- Statewide permit available

## Program Requirements

### Six Minimum Control Measures
1. Public education and outreach
2. Public participation/involvement
3. Illicit discharge detection and elimination
4. Construction site runoff control
5. Post-construction runoff management
6. Pollution prevention/good housekeeping

## Reporting Requirements

### Annual Reports
- Program implementation status
- Monitoring data
- BMP effectiveness
- Public outreach conducted

## TMDL Implementation
- MS4 permits incorporate TMDLs
- Specific pollutant reductions required
- Implementation schedules
- Monitoring obligations

## Low Impact Development (LID)
- Required in most MS4 permits
- Infiltrate, evapotranspire, capture stormwater
- On-site retention
- Biofiltration

## Finding Your MS4 Permit
- Contact city/county public works
- [Regional Board website](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
- [SMARTS database](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov)

## Take Action

1. **Find your MS4 permit** -- Search the [SMARTS database](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov) for your municipality's stormwater enrollment and compliance status.
2. **Contact your Regional Board** -- Use the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to find your Regional Water Quality Control Board for permit-specific questions.
3. **Review stormwater requirements** -- Visit the [SWRCB Stormwater Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/) for the latest municipal stormwater permit information.
4. **Learn about compliance** -- Review the [EPA Municipal Stormwater Program](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/stormwater-discharges-municipal-sources) for federal guidance on MS4 permit obligations.

# Waste Discharge Requirements (WDRs)

## What are WDRs?
California permits for waste discharge to land or waters of the state.

## Types of WDRs

### Individual WDRs
- Facility-specific conditions
- Large or complex dischargers
- Issued by Regional Boards

### General WDRs
- Cover categories of dischargers
- Enrollment through NOI
- Statewide or regional

### Waivers
- Certain low-risk discharges
- Conditional waivers
- Monitoring may be required

## When WDRs Required

### Land Discharge
- Wastewater to land
- Septic system permits
- Agricultural waste
- Mining waste

### Surface Water (without federal NPDES)
- Certain discharges
- Waters of the state only
- State-specific permits

## Application Process

1. Contact your [Regional Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
2. Submit Report of Waste Discharge
3. Technical review
4. Draft permit preparation
5. Public notice
6. Final permit issuance

## Typical Conditions
- Effluent limitations
- Monitoring requirements
- Reporting schedules
- Best management practices
- Facility operation requirements

## Fees
- Annual fees based on threat/complexity
- Application fees
- See the [fee schedule online](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/resources/fees/water_quality/)

## Take Action

1. **Determine if you need a WDR** -- Contact your [Regional Water Quality Control Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to discuss your discharge and whether a WDR, general order, or waiver applies.
2. **Submit a Report of Waste Discharge** -- Visit the [SWRCB WDR Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/waste_discharge_requirements/) page for application forms and instructions.
3. **Check current fees** -- Review the [Water Quality Fee Schedule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/resources/fees/water_quality/) for annual and application fees based on threat and complexity.
4. **Track compliance** -- Use [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) to monitor your permit status, submit reports, and check for violations.

# Water Quality Certification (Section 401)

## What is 401 Certification?
State certification that federal permits comply with water quality standards.

## When Required

### Federal Permits Triggering 401
- Corps of Engineers Section 404 permits
- FERC hydroelectric licenses
- Rivers and Harbors Act permits
- Coast Guard bridge permits

### Activities Needing Certification
- Dredging
- Filling in waters
- Dam construction/modification
- Stream crossings
- Wetland impacts

## Who Issues Certification
- [Regional Water Quality Control Boards](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
- State Water Board (some categories)
- Depends on project type and location

## Application Process

### Pre-Application
- Consultation recommended
- Identify required permits
- Understand water quality issues

### Application Contents
- Project description
- Environmental information
- Proposed mitigation
- CEQA compliance

### Timeframes
- 1 year federal deadline
- Agency review period
- Public notice (some projects)

## Certification Conditions
- Water quality protection measures
- Mitigation requirements
- Monitoring and reporting
- Construction BMPs

## Fees
- Based on project type and impact
- See the [current fee schedule](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/)

## Take Action

1. **Determine if you need 401 certification** -- Review the [CWA 401 Certification Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/) to understand when state certification is required for your federal permit.
2. **Contact your Regional Board** -- Use the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to find the correct Regional Board for your project location.
3. **Schedule a pre-application meeting** -- For complex projects, request a consultation with your Regional Board to clarify requirements and reduce review time.
4. **Calculate fees** -- Use the online fee tool at the [401 Program page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/cwa401/) for an estimate before submitting your application.

# NPDES Permit Monitoring and Reporting

## Self-Monitoring Requirements

### What to Monitor
- Effluent quality parameters
- Flow rates
- Receiving water (some permits)
- Biomonitoring (some permits)

### Monitoring Frequency
- Varies by permit
- Daily, weekly, monthly common
- Depends on discharge type

## Reporting Requirements

### Self-Monitoring Reports (SMRs)
- Submit via CIWQS
- Monthly or quarterly typically
- Include all monitoring data
- Certification statement

### Annual Reports
- Summary of year's compliance
- Exceedances and explanations
- Corrective actions

### Noncompliance Reporting
- 24-hour notification (acute)
- Written follow-up
- Explanation and corrective action

## CIWQS System

### California Integrated Water Quality System
- Online reporting portal
- Electronic submittal required
- Registration needed

**URL**: [ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov)

## Laboratory Requirements

### ELAP Certification
- Labs must be certified
- For each analyte reported
- [Environmental Laboratory Accreditation Program (ELAP)](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/)

### QA/QC
- Method detection limits
- Quality control samples
- Chain of custody

## Record Retention
- Keep records minimum 3-5 years
- Longer if permit specifies
- Available for inspection

## Take Action

1. **Register for CIWQS** -- Enroll in the [CIWQS portal](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) to submit electronic self-monitoring reports and track compliance.
2. **Verify your lab is certified** -- Check the [ELAP Certified Labs directory](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/labs/) to confirm your laboratory holds proper certification for each analyte.
3. **Review your permit conditions** -- Contact your [Regional Water Quality Control Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) if you have questions about monitoring frequency or reporting requirements.
4. **Report noncompliance promptly** -- Provide 24-hour notification for acute violations and written follow-up per your permit conditions. Visit the [SWRCB NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) for guidance.

# Water Quality Enforcement in California

## Types of Enforcement Actions

### Informal
- Warning letters
- Notice of violation
- Compliance assistance

### Formal
- Cleanup and abatement orders
- Cease and desist orders
- Administrative civil liability
- Referral for criminal prosecution

## Administrative Civil Liability (ACL)

### Authority
- [Water Code Section 13385](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/enforcement/)
- Up to $10,000/day per violation
- Higher for certain violations

### Settlement vs Hearing
- Many resolved through settlement
- Contested cases go to hearing
- Board decision final

## Supplemental Environmental Projects (SEPs)

### What are SEPs?
- Environmental projects in lieu of penalties
- Must be environmentally beneficial
- Not required by law

### Examples
- Habitat restoration
- Public education
- Water quality improvement
- Environmental research

## Criminal Enforcement

### When Used
- Knowing violations
- Intentional misconduct
- Falsification of records
- Serious public health threat

### Penalties
- Fines
- Imprisonment possible
- Referred to District Attorney or AG

## Compliance History
- Public record
- Affects permit decisions
- [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) violation data
- [Enforcement orders posted online](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/enforcement/)

## Take Action

1. **Check your compliance status** -- Search [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) for your facility's violation history and any pending enforcement actions.
2. **Understand the enforcement process** -- Review the [SWRCB Enforcement Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/enforcement/) to understand the progression from informal to formal enforcement.
3. **Consider a Supplemental Environmental Project** -- If facing penalties, explore SEP options through your [Regional Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to convert fines into beneficial environmental projects.
4. **Maintain records** -- Keep all monitoring data, maintenance logs, and correspondence for at least 5 years to demonstrate good-faith compliance efforts.

# Public Records and Water Quality Data

## Accessing Water Quality Information

### [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov)
- Permit information
- Violation data
- Enforcement actions
- Monitoring data

### [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov)
- Cleanup sites
- Underground storage tanks
- Site investigation reports
- Case status

### [SMARTS](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov)
- Stormwater permit enrollment
- Annual reports
- NOI/NOT filings
- Compliance status

## Consumer Confidence Reports

### Annual Reports
- Required for community water systems
- Distributed by July 1
- Source water information
- Detected contaminants
- Compliance status

### Where to Find
- Water utility website
- Request from utility
- DDW database

## Public Records Act Requests

### How to Request
- Written request preferred
- Describe records sought
- Agency must respond timely

### Response Time
- 10 days to determine disclosability
- May request extension
- Some exemptions apply

### Fees
- Copies may have fee
- Electronic delivery may be free
- No fee to inspect

## Public Participation

### Permit Hearings
- Notice provided
- Public comment period
- Oral testimony opportunity

### Board Meetings
- Open to public
- Public comment periods
- Agendas posted online

## Take Action

1. **Search water quality databases** -- Access [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) for permits and violations, [GeoTracker](https://geotracker.waterboards.ca.gov) for cleanup sites, and [SMARTS](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov) for stormwater data.
2. **Find your CCR** -- Locate your Consumer Confidence Report through [DDW's Annual Reports page](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/drinkingwater/CCR.html) or your utility's website.
3. **File a Public Records Act request** -- Submit a written request to the [SWRCB Public Records](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/resources/public_records/) office for documents not available online.
4. **Attend a Board meeting** -- Check the [SWRCB Board Meeting Calendar](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/board_info/calendar/) for upcoming public meetings and comment opportunities.

# Dewatering and Temporary Discharge Permits

## What is Dewatering?
Removing groundwater from construction sites or other locations.

## When Permits Required

### Construction Dewatering
- Excavations below water table
- Foundation construction
- Utility installation

### Well Development
- New well drilling
- Pump testing

### Other Temporary Discharges
- Hydrostatic testing
- Tank cleaning
- Pool/spa draining

## Permit Options

### General Permits
- Statewide general permit for dewatering
- Low threat discharge general permit
- Enrollment through NOI

### Individual Permits
- Large or complex projects
- Contaminated groundwater
- Longer duration

## Typical Requirements

### Water Quality
- Meet discharge limits
- Treatment if needed
- Monitoring required

### BMPs
- Sediment control
- Pollution prevention
- Spill containment

### Discharge Location
- Storm drain (if permitted)
- Sanitary sewer (with POT permit)
- Land application

## Fees and Timeline
- Application fees
- Annual fees if ongoing
- Processing time varies

## Resources
- [Regional Board general permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html)
- Low threat discharge guidance
- Pre-application consultation with your [Regional Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) is recommended

## Take Action

1. **Determine your permit type** -- Visit the [SWRCB NPDES General Permits](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/general_permits.html) page to find the appropriate general permit for dewatering or temporary discharges.
2. **Enroll via SMARTS** -- Submit your Notice of Intent through the [SMARTS portal](https://smarts.waterboards.ca.gov) for construction and stormwater-related dewatering.
3. **Contact your Regional Board** -- Use the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to find the right Regional Board for pre-application consultation on complex or contaminated dewatering projects.
4. **Implement BMPs** -- Review [construction stormwater BMPs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/stormwater/constpermits.html) for sediment control, pollution prevention, and spill containment requirements.

# Industrial Pretreatment Programs

## What is Pretreatment?
Treating industrial wastewater before discharge to municipal sewer system.

## Why Pretreatment Required

### Protect POTW
- Prevent interference with treatment
- Protect collection system
- Meet POTW permit limits

### Prevent Pass-Through
- Pollutants passing through untreated
- Protect receiving water
- Meet NPDES permit limits

## Who Requires Pretreatment?

### POTWs with Pretreatment Programs
- Required for POTWs >5 MGD
- Significant industrial users
- Approved by EPA/State

### Categorical Industries
- Federal categories with specific limits
- Metal finishing
- Electroplating
- Pharmaceutical manufacturing
- Many others

## Industrial User Requirements

### Discharge Permits
- From POTW, not the [Water Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
- Facility-specific limits
- Monitoring requirements
- Reporting

### Categorical Standards
- Meet federal categorical limits
- Or local limits (whichever more stringent)
- Technology-based standards

## Monitoring and Reporting

### Self-Monitoring
- Required by permit
- Certified lab analysis
- Records retention

### Reports
- Semi-annual compliance reports
- Baseline monitoring reports
- Noncompliance notifications

## Enforcement
- POTW has primary authority
- [Water Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) oversight
- EPA oversight of programs

## Take Action

1. **Contact your local POTW** -- Industrial discharge permits come from your municipal wastewater treatment plant, not the Water Board. Ask your POTW about pretreatment requirements and local limits.
2. **Check categorical standards** -- Review [EPA Pretreatment Standards](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/industrial-pretreatment) to determine if federal categorical standards apply to your industry.
3. **Find your Regional Board** -- Visit the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) to identify your Regional Board for state-level questions about pretreatment programs.
4. **Track compliance via CIWQS** -- Use [CIWQS](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) to review permit data and ensure monitoring reports are filed on time.

# Operator Certification for Water Systems

## Why Certification Required
Ensures operators have knowledge to:
- Protect public health
- Properly operate treatment
- Maintain compliance
- Respond to emergencies

## Types of Certification

### Water Treatment Operator
- Grades T1-T5
- Based on treatment complexity
- Exam required

### Water Distribution Operator
- Grades D1-D5
- Based on system size/complexity
- Separate from treatment

### Small Water System Operator
- For small systems
- Less complex requirements
- Training-based option

## Certification Requirements

### Education
- High school or equivalent
- College credits may be required for higher grades

### Experience
- Years of experience required
- Varies by grade level
- Must be supervised

### Examination
- Proctored exam
- Multiple choice format
- Passing score required

## Continuing Education

### Contact Hours
- Required for renewal
- Every 3 years
- Approved courses only

### Topics
- Regulatory updates
- Treatment technology
- Distribution operations
- Safety

## Finding Certified Operators
- [State Board operator certification database](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/)
- Contract operators
- Technical assistance providers through [DDW](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/)

## Take Action

1. **Check certification requirements** -- Visit the [DDW Operator Certification Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/) for exam schedules, grade requirements, and application forms.
2. **Find continuing education** -- Browse approved courses through [DDW's certification portal](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/) to maintain your contact hours for renewal.
3. **Explore technical assistance** -- Small systems can access help through the [DDW Drinking Water Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) office.
4. **Verify operator credentials** -- Use the [State Board database](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/certlic/occupations/) to confirm current certification status for any water system operator.

# Sanitary Survey Requirements

## What is a Sanitary Survey?
Comprehensive inspection of water system by regulatory agency.

## Who Conducts Surveys
- [DDW](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) staff (drinking water)
- Local primacy agencies
- Authorized inspectors

## Survey Frequency

### Community Water Systems
- Every 3 years for groundwater
- Every 3 years for surface water
- More frequent if problems

### Non-Community Systems
- Every 5 years typically
- Based on risk factors

## Elements Evaluated

### Eight Elements
1. Source
2. Treatment
3. Distribution system
4. Finished water storage
5. Pumps, pumping facilities, and controls
6. Monitoring, reporting, and data verification
7. System management and operation
8. Operator compliance

## Survey Outcomes

### Significant Deficiencies
- Must be corrected
- Compliance schedule
- Follow-up verification

### Recommendations
- Best practices
- Not mandatory
- Improve operations

## Preparing for Survey

### Have Available
- Operations records
- Monitoring data
- Maintenance logs
- Emergency plans
- Training records

### Physical Inspection
- Clean facilities
- Operational equipment
- Proper security
- Adequate signage

## Take Action

1. **Prepare for your next survey** -- Gather operations records, monitoring data, maintenance logs, and emergency plans. Review the [DDW Drinking Water Programs](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/) page for survey guidance.
2. **Address significant deficiencies** -- If your last survey identified issues, create a corrective action plan and track it through your [DDW District Office](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/districts/).
3. **Review the eight elements** -- Ensure your system meets requirements for all eight survey elements. Visit the [EPA Sanitary Survey guidance](https://www.epa.gov/dwreginfo) for detailed checklists.
4. **Contact DDW** -- Reach your local [DDW District Office](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/drinking_water/programs/districts/) to ask about your survey schedule and how to prepare.
